item In other projects Wikidata item Wikidata item Wikidata item Wikidata item Wikidata item       From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia                                 .mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-left:10px solid #36c;background-color:#fbfbfb;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+link+.ambox{margin-top:-1px}html body.mediawiki .mw-parser-output .ambox.mbox-small-left{margin:4px 1em 4px 0;overflow:hidden;width:238px;border-collapse:collapse;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em}.mw-parser-output .ambox-speedy{border-left:10px solid #b32424;background-color:#fee7e6}.mw-parser-output .ambox-delete{border-left:10px solid #b32424}.mw-parser-output .ambox-content{border-left:10px solid #f28500}.mw-parser-output .ambox-style{border-left:10px solid #fc3}.mw-parser-output .ambox-move{border-left:10px solid #9932cc}.mw-parser-output .ambox-protection{border-left:10px solid #a2a9b1}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-text{border:none;padding:0.25em 0.5em;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image{border:none;padding:2px 0 2px 0.5em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-imageright{border:none;padding:2px 0.5em 2px 0;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-empty-cell{border:none;padding:0;width:1px}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image-div{width:52px}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .ambox{margin:0 10%}}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .ambox{display:none!important}}This article needs additional citations for verification. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR  (February 2008) (Learn how and when to remove this message) Grameen Danone Foods, popularly known as Grameen Danone, is a social business enterprise, launched in 2006, which has been designed to provide children with many of the key nutrients that are typically missing from their diet in rural Bangladesh.  It is run on 'No loss, No dividend' basis. Initially, Grameen Danone agreed to pay an annual dividend of one percent to shareholders, however, in December 2009, the board of Grameen Danone agreed to waive any monetary return.[1]   History[edit] During his visit to Paris, France, in 2005, Muhammad Yunus, the founder of Grameen Bank was invited by Franck Riboud, the chief executive officer of Groupe Danone (known as Dannon in the US).  On 12 October 2005, they met in La Fontaine Gaillon, a Parisian restaurant.  There Yunus proposed to form a joint venture between Grameen and Danone with the objective of supplying nutritious food to poor children of Bangladesh.  As proposed by Muhammad Yunus, Franck Riboud agreed to participate in the project to be styled a social business.[2] Accordingly, the Grameen Group and Groupe Danone entered into an agreement to form a company called Grameen Danone Foods – a social business in Bangladesh.[3] The objective was to bring daily healthy nutrition to low income nutritionally deprived populations in Bangladesh and alleviate poverty through the implementation of a community based business model, where no profit will be appropriated by the investing partners.[4] The launch of Grameen Danone received considerable attention and was attended by celebrities including French soccer player Zinedine Zidane of France.[5] Grameen Danone was led by Corinne Bazina from 2010 to 2014, Eric Ipavec from 2014 to 2016, Valérie Mazon from 2017 to 2018, and Dipesh Nag since 2020.  Products and price[edit] Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. produces a yoghurt called Shokti Doi containing protein, vitamins, iron, calcium, zinc and other micronutrients aimed to fill nutritional deficits of children in Bangladesh.  'Shokti Doi' (which means 'strength yoghurt') is primarily intended for children. In 2017, a 50g cup sold for 10 Taka and 80g cup for 40 taka.  Objective[edit] Grameen Danone Foods aims to reduce poverty by creating business and employment opportunities for local people since raw materials including milk needed for production, will be sourced locally.  The companies that make up Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. have agreed not to take out any of the profits out of the company.  Instead they will invest these for creation of new opportunities for the welfare and development of people.  Hence it is called 'social business enterprise'.[4]  Production capacity[edit] Grameen Danone has planned to set up and launch as many as 50 production plants during the ten years between 2006 and 2016.[6] The first factory has been built in Bogra district which is about 230 kilometres (140 mi) north of Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh.  The first factory is a small one built upon an area of 7,000 sq ft (650 m2).[7] Its daily production capacity was 3,000 kilograms (6,600 lb) of yogurt when launched in 2006. In 2008, the production capacity has been planned to be enhanced to 10,000 kilograms (22,000 lb) and beyond.  Several hundred livestock-farming and distribution jobs would be created in the local community as a result of establishment of the first factory.[4] As of 2011, the company had not opened another factory.[8]  Challenges[edit] Grameen Danone maintains strict quality control for Shokti Doi. The cold chain is maintained all the way from production to the end consumers. But maintaining cold chain is very expensive in Bangladesh as the traffic gridlock is a common scenario. Costly transportation is eating up a big portion of the return, thus could not reach its break-even till date. ol>li:first-child::before{content:\" (\"counter(listitem)\"\\a0 \"}.mw-parser-output .navbox{box-sizing:border-box;border:1px solid #a2a9b1;width:100%;clear:both;font-size:88%;text-align:center;padding:1px;margin:1em auto 0}.mw-parser-output .navbox .navbox{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .navbox+.navbox,.mw-parser-output .navbox-title,.mw-parser-output .navbox-abovebelow{padding:0.25em 1em;line-height:1.5em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .navbox-group{white-space:nowrap;text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .navbox-list-with-group{text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid}.mw-parser-output tr+tr>.navbox-abovebelow,.mw-parser-output tr+tr>.navbox-group,.mw-parser-output references From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia  From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia   .mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-left:10px solid #36c;background-color:#fbfbfb;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+link+.ambox{margin-top:-1px}html body.mediawiki .mw-parser-output .ambox.mbox-small-left{margin:4px 1em 4px 0;overflow:hidden;width:238px;border-collapse:collapse;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em}.mw-parser-output .ambox-speedy{border-left:10px solid #b32424;background-color:#fee7e6}.mw-parser-output .ambox-delete{border-left:10px solid #b32424}.mw-parser-output .ambox-content{border-left:10px solid #f28500}.mw-parser-output .ambox-style{border-left:10px solid #fc3}.mw-parser-output .ambox-move{border-left:10px solid #9932cc}.mw-parser-output .ambox-protection{border-left:10px solid #a2a9b1}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-text{border:none;padding:0.25em 0.5em;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image{border:none;padding:2px 0 2px 0.5em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-imageright{border:none;padding:2px 0.5em 2px 0;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-empty-cell{border:none;padding:0;width:1px}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image-div{width:52px}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .ambox{margin:0 10%}}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .ambox{display:none!important}}This article needs additional citations for verification. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR  (February 2008) (Learn how and when to remove this message) Grameen Danone Foods, popularly known as Grameen Danone, is a social business enterprise, launched in 2006, which has been designed to provide children with many of the key nutrients that are typically missing from their diet in rural Bangladesh.  It is run on 'No loss, No dividend' basis. Initially, Grameen Danone agreed to pay an annual dividend of one percent to shareholders, however, in December 2009, the board of Grameen Danone agreed to waive any monetary return.[1]   History[edit] During his visit to Paris, France, in 2005, Muhammad Yunus, the founder of Grameen Bank was invited by Franck Riboud, the chief executive officer of Groupe Danone (known as Dannon in the US).  On 12 October 2005, they met in La Fontaine Gaillon, a Parisian restaurant.  There Yunus proposed to form a joint venture between Grameen and Danone with the objective of supplying nutritious food to poor children of Bangladesh.  As proposed by Muhammad Yunus, Franck Riboud agreed to participate in the project to be styled a social business.[2] Accordingly, the Grameen Group and Groupe Danone entered into an agreement to form a company called Grameen Danone Foods – a social business in Bangladesh.[3] The objective was to bring daily healthy nutrition to low income nutritionally deprived populations in Bangladesh and alleviate poverty through the implementation of a community based business model, where no profit will be appropriated by the investing partners.[4] The launch of Grameen Danone received considerable attention and was attended by celebrities including French soccer player Zinedine Zidane of France.[5] Grameen Danone was led by Corinne Bazina from 2010 to 2014, Eric Ipavec from 2014 to 2016, Valérie Mazon from 2017 to 2018, and Dipesh Nag since 2020.  Products and price[edit] Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. produces a yoghurt called Shokti Doi containing protein, vitamins, iron, calcium, zinc and other micronutrients aimed to fill nutritional deficits of children in Bangladesh.  'Shokti Doi' (which means 'strength yoghurt') is primarily intended for children. In 2017, a 50g cup sold for 10 Taka and 80g cup for 40 taka.  Objective[edit] Grameen Danone Foods aims to reduce poverty by creating business and employment opportunities for local people since raw materials including milk needed for production, will be sourced locally.  The companies that make up Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. have agreed not to take out any of the profits out of the company.  Instead they will invest these for creation of new opportunities for the welfare and development of people.  Hence it is called 'social business enterprise'.[4]  Production capacity[edit] Grameen Danone has planned to set up and launch as many as 50 production plants during the ten years between 2006 and 2016.[6] The first factory has been built in Bogra district which is about 230 kilometres (140 mi) north of Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh.  The first factory is a small one built upon an area of 7,000 sq ft (650 m2).[7] Its daily production capacity was 3,000 kilograms (6,600 lb) of yogurt when launched in 2006. In 2008, the production capacity has been planned to be enhanced to 10,000 kilograms (22,000 lb) and beyond.  Several hundred livestock-farming and distribution jobs would be created in the local community as a result of establishment of the first factory.[4] As of 2011, the company had not opened another factory.[8]  Challenges[edit] Grameen Danone maintains strict quality control for Shokti Doi. The cold chain is maintained all the way from production to the end consumers. But maintaining cold chain is very expensive in Bangladesh as the traffic gridlock is a common scenario. Costly transportation is eating up a big portion of the return, thus could not reach its break-even till date. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR  (February 2008) (Learn how and when to remove this message) Grameen Danone Foods, popularly known as Grameen Danone, is a social business enterprise, launched in 2006, which has been designed to provide children with many of the key nutrients that are typically missing from their diet in rural Bangladesh.  It is run on 'No loss, No dividend' basis. Initially, Grameen Danone agreed to pay an annual dividend of one percent to shareholders, however, in December 2009, the board of Grameen Danone agreed to waive any monetary return.[1]   History[edit] During his visit to Paris, France, in 2005, Muhammad Yunus, the founder of Grameen Bank was invited by Franck Riboud, the chief executive officer of Groupe Danone (known as Dannon in the US).  On 12 October 2005, they met in La Fontaine Gaillon, a Parisian restaurant.  There Yunus proposed to form a joint venture between Grameen and Danone with the objective of supplying nutritious food to poor children of Bangladesh.  As proposed by Muhammad Yunus, Franck Riboud agreed to participate in the project to be styled a social business.[2] Accordingly, the Grameen Group and Groupe Danone entered into an agreement to form a company called Grameen Danone Foods – a social business in Bangladesh.[3] The objective was to bring daily healthy nutrition to low income nutritionally deprived populations in Bangladesh and alleviate poverty through the implementation of a community based business model, where no profit will be appropriated by the investing partners.[4] The launch of Grameen Danone received considerable attention and was attended by celebrities including French soccer player Zinedine Zidane of France.[5] Grameen Danone was led by Corinne Bazina from 2010 to 2014, Eric Ipavec from 2014 to 2016, Valérie Mazon from 2017 to 2018, and Dipesh Nag since 2020.  Products and price[edit] Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. produces a yoghurt called Shokti Doi containing protein, vitamins, iron, calcium, zinc and other micronutrients aimed to fill nutritional deficits of children in Bangladesh.  'Shokti Doi' (which means 'strength yoghurt') is primarily intended for children. In 2017, a 50g cup sold for 10 Taka and 80g cup for 40 taka.  Objective[edit] Grameen Danone Foods aims to reduce poverty by creating business and employment opportunities for local people since raw materials including milk needed for production, will be sourced locally.  The companies that make up Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. have agreed not to take out any of the profits out of the company.  Instead they will invest these for creation of new opportunities for the welfare and development of people.  Hence it is called 'social business enterprise'.[4]  Production capacity[edit] Grameen Danone has planned to set up and launch as many as 50 production plants during the ten years between 2006 and 2016.[6] The first factory has been built in Bogra district which is about 230 kilometres (140 mi) north of Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh.  The first factory is a small one built upon an area of 7,000 sq ft (650 m2).[7] Its daily production capacity was 3,000 kilograms (6,600 lb) of yogurt when launched in 2006. In 2008, the production capacity has been planned to be enhanced to 10,000 kilograms (22,000 lb) and beyond.  Several hundred livestock-farming and distribution jobs would be created in the local community as a result of establishment of the first factory.[4] As of 2011, the company had not opened another factory.[8]  Challenges[edit] Grameen Danone maintains strict quality control for Shokti Doi. The cold chain is maintained all the way from production to the end consumers. But maintaining cold chain is very expensive in Bangladesh as the traffic gridlock is a common scenario. Costly transportation is eating up a big portion of the return, thus could not reach its break-even till date. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR  (February 2008) (Learn how and when to remove this message) needs additional citations for verification verification Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR improve this article adding citations to reliable sources  Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR (February 2008) (February 2008) February 2008 (Learn how and when to remove this message) (Learn how and when to remove this message) Learn how and when to remove this message Learn how and when to remove this message Grameen Danone Foods, popularly known as Grameen Danone, is a social business enterprise, launched in 2006, which has been designed to provide children with many of the key nutrients that are typically missing from their diet in rural Bangladesh.  It is run on 'No loss, No dividend' basis. Initially, Grameen Danone agreed to pay an annual dividend of one percent to shareholders, however, in December 2009, the board of Grameen Danone agreed to waive any monetary return.[1] Grameen Danone Foods Grameen Danone social business enterprise nutrients Bangladesh shareholders [1] [1] [ ]  History[edit] History [edit] [ edit edit ] During his visit to Paris, France, in 2005, Muhammad Yunus, the founder of Grameen Bank was invited by Franck Riboud, the chief executive officer of Groupe Danone (known as Dannon in the US).  On 12 October 2005, they met in La Fontaine Gaillon, a Parisian restaurant.  There Yunus proposed to form a joint venture between Grameen and Danone with the objective of supplying nutritious food to poor children of Bangladesh.  As proposed by Muhammad Yunus, Franck Riboud agreed to participate in the project to be styled a social business.[2] Accordingly, the Grameen Group and Groupe Danone entered into an agreement to form a company called Grameen Danone Foods – a social business in Bangladesh.[3] The objective was to bring daily healthy nutrition to low income nutritionally deprived populations in Bangladesh and alleviate poverty through the implementation of a community based business model, where no profit will be appropriated by the investing partners.[4] Muhammad Yunus Grameen Bank Groupe Danone Grameen Danone social business [2] [2] [ ] social business [3] [3] [ ] [4] [4] [ ] The launch of Grameen Danone received considerable attention and was attended by celebrities including French soccer player Zinedine Zidane of France.[5] Zinedine Zidane [5] [5] [ ] Grameen Danone was led by Corinne Bazina from 2010 to 2014, Eric Ipavec from 2014 to 2016, Valérie Mazon from 2017 to 2018, and Dipesh Nag since 2020. Products and price[edit] Products and price [edit] [ edit edit ] Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. produces a yoghurt called Shokti Doi containing protein, vitamins, iron, calcium, zinc and other micronutrients aimed to fill nutritional deficits of children in Bangladesh.  'Shokti Doi' (which means 'strength yoghurt') is primarily intended for children. In 2017, a 50g cup sold for 10 Taka and 80g cup for 40 taka. Shokti Doi protein vitamins calcium zinc micronutrients Objective[edit] Objective [edit] [ edit edit ] Grameen Danone Foods aims to reduce poverty by creating business and employment opportunities for local people since raw materials including milk needed for production, will be sourced locally.  The companies that make up Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. have agreed not to take out any of the profits out of the company.  Instead they will invest these for creation of new opportunities for the welfare and development of people.  Hence it is called 'social business enterprise'.[4] [4] [4] [ ] Production capacity[edit] Production capacity [edit] [ edit edit ] Grameen Danone has planned to set up and launch as many as 50 production plants during the ten years between 2006 and 2016.[6] The first factory has been built in Bogra district which is about 230 kilometres (140 mi) north of Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh.  The first factory is a small one built upon an area of 7,000 sq ft (650 m2).[7] Its daily production capacity was 3,000 kilograms (6,600 lb) of yogurt when launched in 2006. In 2008, the production capacity has been planned to be enhanced to 10,000 kilograms (22,000 lb) and beyond.  Several hundred livestock-farming and distribution jobs would be created in the local community as a result of establishment of the first factory.[4] As of 2011, the company had not opened another factory.[8] [6] [6] [ ] Bogra Dhaka 2 [7] [7] [ ] [4] [4] [ ] [8] [8] [ ] Challenges[edit] Challenges [edit] [ edit edit ] Grameen Danone maintains strict quality control for Shokti Doi. The cold chain is maintained all the way from production to the end consumers. But maintaining cold chain is very expensive in Bangladesh as the traffic gridlock is a common scenario. Costly transportation is eating up a big portion of the return, thus could not reach its break-even till date. cold chain References[edit] References [edit] [ edit edit ] .mw-parser-output     "From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia                                 .mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-left:10px solid #36c;background-color:#fbfbfb;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+link+.ambox{margin-top:-1px}html body.mediawiki .mw-parser-output .ambox.mbox-small-left{margin:4px 1em 4px 0;overflow:hidden;width:238px;border-collapse:collapse;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em}.mw-parser-output .ambox-speedy{border-left:10px solid #b32424;background-color:#fee7e6}.mw-parser-output .ambox-delete{border-left:10px solid #b32424}.mw-parser-output .ambox-content{border-left:10px solid #f28500}.mw-parser-output .ambox-style{border-left:10px solid #fc3}.mw-parser-output .ambox-move{border-left:10px solid #9932cc}.mw-parser-output .ambox-protection{border-left:10px solid #a2a9b1}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-text{border:none;padding:0.25em 0.5em;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image{border:none;padding:2px 0 2px 0.5em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-imageright{border:none;padding:2px 0.5em 2px 0;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-empty-cell{border:none;padding:0;width:1px}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image-div{width:52px}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .ambox{margin:0 10%}}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .ambox{display:none!important}}This article needs additional citations for verification. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR  (February 2008) (Learn how and when to remove this message) Grameen Danone Foods, popularly known as Grameen Danone, is a social business enterprise, launched in 2006, which has been designed to provide children with many of the key nutrients that are typically missing from their diet in rural Bangladesh.  It is run on 'No loss, No dividend' basis. Initially, Grameen Danone agreed to pay an annual dividend of one percent to shareholders, however, in December 2009, the board of Grameen Danone agreed to waive any monetary return.[1]   History[edit] During his visit to Paris, France, in 2005, Muhammad Yunus, the founder of Grameen Bank was invited by Franck Riboud, the chief executive officer of Groupe Danone (known as Dannon in the US).  On 12 October 2005, they met in La Fontaine Gaillon, a Parisian restaurant.  There Yunus proposed to form a joint venture between Grameen and Danone with the objective of supplying nutritious food to poor children of Bangladesh.  As proposed by Muhammad Yunus, Franck Riboud agreed to participate in the project to be styled a social business.[2] Accordingly, the Grameen Group and Groupe Danone entered into an agreement to form a company called Grameen Danone Foods – a social business in Bangladesh.[3] The objective was to bring daily healthy nutrition to low income nutritionally deprived populations in Bangladesh and alleviate poverty through the implementation of a community based business model, where no profit will be appropriated by the investing partners.[4] The launch of Grameen Danone received considerable attention and was attended by celebrities including French soccer player Zinedine Zidane of France.[5] Grameen Danone was led by Corinne Bazina from 2010 to 2014, Eric Ipavec from 2014 to 2016, Valérie Mazon from 2017 to 2018, and Dipesh Nag since 2020.  Products and price[edit] Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. produces a yoghurt called Shokti Doi containing protein, vitamins, iron, calcium, zinc and other micronutrients aimed to fill nutritional deficits of children in Bangladesh.  'Shokti Doi' (which means 'strength yoghurt') is primarily intended for children. In 2017, a 50g cup sold for 10 Taka and 80g cup for 40 taka.  Objective[edit] Grameen Danone Foods aims to reduce poverty by creating business and employment opportunities for local people since raw materials including milk needed for production, will be sourced locally.  The companies that make up Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. have agreed not to take out any of the profits out of the company.  Instead they will invest these for creation of new opportunities for the welfare and development of people.  Hence it is called 'social business enterprise'.[4]  Production capacity[edit] Grameen Danone has planned to set up and launch as many as 50 production plants during the ten years between 2006 and 2016.[6] The first factory has been built in Bogra district which is about 230 kilometres (140 mi) north of Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh.  The first factory is a small one built upon an area of 7,000 sq ft (650 m2).[7] Its daily production capacity was 3,000 kilograms (6,600 lb) of yogurt when launched in 2006. In 2008, the production capacity has been planned to be enhanced to 10,000 kilograms (22,000 lb) and beyond.  Several hundred livestock-farming and distribution jobs would be created in the local community as a result of establishment of the first factory.[4] As of 2011, the company had not opened another factory.[8]  Challenges[edit] Grameen Danone maintains strict quality control for Shokti Doi. The cold chain is maintained all the way from production to the end consumers. But maintaining cold chain is very expensive in Bangladesh as the traffic gridlock is a common scenario. Costly transportation is eating up a big portion of the return, thus could not reach its break-even till date. .ambox.mbox-small-left{margin:4px 1em 4px 0;overflow:hidden;width:238px;border-collapse:collapse;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em}.mw-parser-output .ambox-speedy{border-left:10px solid .mbox-text{border:none;padding:0.25em 0.5em;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image{border:none;padding:2px 0 2px 0.5em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-imageright{border:none;padding:2px 0.5em 2px 0;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-empty-cell{border:none;padding:0;width:1px}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image-div{width:52px}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .ambox{margin:0 10%}}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .ambox{display:none!important}}This article needs additional citations for verification. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR  (February 2008) (Learn how and when to remove this message) Grameen Danone Foods, popularly known as Grameen Danone, is a social business enterprise, launched in 2006, which has been designed to provide children with many of the key nutrients that are typically missing from their diet in rural Bangladesh.  It is run on 'No loss, No dividend' basis. Initially, Grameen Danone agreed to pay an annual dividend of one percent to shareholders, however, in December 2009, the board of Grameen Danone agreed to waive any monetary return.[1]   History[edit] During his visit to Paris, France, in 2005, Muhammad Yunus, the founder of Grameen Bank was invited by Franck Riboud, the chief executive officer of Groupe Danone (known as Dannon in the US).  On 12 October 2005, they met in La Fontaine Gaillon, a Parisian restaurant.  There Yunus proposed to form a joint venture between Grameen and Danone with the objective of supplying nutritious food to poor children of Bangladesh.  As proposed by Muhammad Yunus, Franck Riboud agreed to participate in the project to be styled a social business.[2] Accordingly, the Grameen Group and Groupe Danone entered into an agreement to form a company called Grameen Danone Foods – a social business in Bangladesh.[3] The objective was to bring daily healthy nutrition to low income nutritionally deprived populations in Bangladesh and alleviate poverty through the implementation of a community based business model, where no profit will be appropriated by the investing partners.[4] The launch of Grameen Danone received considerable attention and was attended by celebrities including French soccer player Zinedine Zidane of France.[5] Grameen Danone was led by Corinne Bazina from 2010 to 2014, Eric Ipavec from 2014 to 2016, Valérie Mazon from 2017 to 2018, and Dipesh Nag since 2020.  Products and price[edit] Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. produces a yoghurt called Shokti Doi containing protein, vitamins, iron, calcium, zinc and other micronutrients aimed to fill nutritional deficits of children in Bangladesh.  'Shokti Doi' (which means 'strength yoghurt') is primarily intended for children. In 2017, a 50g cup sold for 10 Taka and 80g cup for 40 taka.  Objective[edit] Grameen Danone Foods aims to reduce poverty by creating business and employment opportunities for local people since raw materials including milk needed for production, will be sourced locally.  The companies that make up Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. have agreed not to take out any of the profits out of the company.  Instead they will invest these for creation of new opportunities for the welfare and development of people.  Hence it is called 'social business enterprise'.[4]  Production capacity[edit] Grameen Danone has planned to set up and launch as many as 50 production plants during the ten years between 2006 and 2016.[6] The first factory has been built in Bogra district which is about 230 kilometres (140 mi) north of Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh.  The first factory is a small one built upon an area of 7,000 sq ft (650 m2).[7] Its daily production capacity was 3,000 kilograms (6,600 lb) of yogurt when launched in 2006. In 2008, the production capacity has been planned to be enhanced to 10,000 kilograms (22,000 lb) and beyond.  Several hundred livestock-farming and distribution jobs would be created in the local community as a result of establishment of the first factory.[4] As of 2011, the company had not opened another factory.[8]  Challenges[edit] Grameen Danone maintains strict quality control for Shokti Doi. The cold chain is maintained all the way from production to the end consumers. But maintaining cold chain is very expensive in Bangladesh as the traffic gridlock is a common scenario. Costly transportation is eating up a big portion of the return, thus could not reach its break-even till date. States     <img src=\"https://login.wikimedia.org/wiki/Special:CentralAutoLogin/start?type=1x1\" alt=\"\" width=\"1\" height=\"1\" style=\"border: none; position: absolute;\"> Retrieved from \"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Grameen_Danone&oldid=1209449515\" .mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-left:10px solid #36c;background-color:#fbfbfb;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+link+.ambox{margin-top:-1px}html body.mediawiki .mw-parser-output .ambox.mbox-small-left{margin:4px 1em 4px 0;overflow:hidden;width:238px;border-collapse:collapse;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em}.mw-parser-output .ambox-speedy{border-left:10px solid #b32424;background-color:#fee7e6}.mw-parser-output .ambox-delete{border-left:10px solid #b32424}.mw-parser-output .ambox-content{border-left:10px solid #f28500}.mw-parser-output .ambox-style{border-left:10px solid #fc3}.mw-parser-output .ambox-move{border-left:10px solid #9932cc}.mw-parser-output .ambox-protection{border-left:10px solid #a2a9b1}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-text{border:none;padding:0.25em 0.5em;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image{border:none;padding:2px 0 2px 0.5em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-imageright{border:none;padding:2px 0.5em 2px 0;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-empty-cell{border:none;padding:0;width:1px}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image-div{width:52px}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .ambox{margin:0 10%}}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .ambox{display:none!important}}This article needs additional citations for verification. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR  (February 2008) (Learn how and when to remove this message) Grameen Danone Foods, popularly known as Grameen Danone, is a social business enterprise, launched in 2006, which has been designed to provide children with many of the key nutrients that are typically missing from their diet in rural Bangladesh.  It is run on 'No loss, No dividend' basis. Initially, Grameen Danone agreed to pay an annual dividend of one percent to shareholders, however, in December 2009, the board of Grameen Danone agreed to waive any monetary return.[1]   History[edit] During his visit to Paris, France, in 2005, Muhammad Yunus, the founder of Grameen Bank was invited by Franck Riboud, the chief executive officer of Groupe Danone (known as Dannon in the US).  On 12 October 2005, they met in La Fontaine Gaillon, a Parisian restaurant.  There Yunus proposed to form a joint venture between Grameen and Danone with the objective of supplying nutritious food to poor children of Bangladesh.  As proposed by Muhammad Yunus, Franck Riboud agreed to participate in the project to be styled a social business.[2] Accordingly, the Grameen Group and Groupe Danone entered into an agreement to form a company called Grameen Danone Foods – a social business in Bangladesh.[3] The objective was to bring daily healthy nutrition to low income nutritionally deprived populations in Bangladesh and alleviate poverty through the implementation of a community based business model, where no profit will be appropriated by the investing partners.[4] The launch of Grameen Danone received considerable attention and was attended by celebrities including French soccer player Zinedine Zidane of France.[5] Grameen Danone was led by Corinne Bazina from 2010 to 2014, Eric Ipavec from 2014 to 2016, Valérie Mazon from 2017 to 2018, and Dipesh Nag since 2020.  Products and price[edit] Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. produces a yoghurt called Shokti Doi containing protein, vitamins, iron, calcium, zinc and other micronutrients aimed to fill nutritional deficits of children in Bangladesh.  'Shokti Doi' (which means 'strength yoghurt') is primarily intended for children. In 2017, a 50g cup sold for 10 Taka and 80g cup for 40 taka.  Objective[edit] Grameen Danone Foods aims to reduce poverty by creating business and employment opportunities for local people since raw materials including milk needed for production, will be sourced locally.  The companies that make up Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. have agreed not to take out any of the profits out of the company.  Instead they will invest these for creation of new opportunities for the welfare and development of people.  Hence it is called 'social business enterprise'.[4]  Production capacity[edit] Grameen Danone has planned to set up and launch as many as 50 production plants during the ten years between 2006 and 2016.[6] The first factory has been built in Bogra district which is about 230 kilometres (140 mi) north of Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh.  The first factory is a small one built upon an area of 7,000 sq ft (650 m2).[7] Its daily production capacity was 3,000 kilograms (6,600 lb) of yogurt when launched in 2006. In 2008, the production capacity has been planned to be enhanced to 10,000 kilograms (22,000 lb) and beyond.  Several hundred livestock-farming and distribution jobs would be created in the local community as a result of establishment of the first factory.[4] As of 2011, the company had not opened another factory.[8]  Challenges[edit] Grameen Danone maintains strict quality control for Shokti Doi. The cold chain is maintained all the way from production to the end consumers. But maintaining cold chain is very expensive in Bangladesh as the traffic gridlock is a common scenario. Costly transportation is eating up a big portion of the return, thus could not reach its break-even till date. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR improve this article adding citations to reliable sources  Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR (February 2008) (February 2008) February 2008 (Learn how and when to remove this message) (Learn how and when to remove this message) Learn how and when to remove this message Learn how and when to remove this message Grameen Danone Foods, popularly known as Grameen Danone, is a social business enterprise, launched in 2006, which has been designed to provide children with many of the key nutrients that are typically missing from their diet in rural Bangladesh.  It is run on 'No loss, No dividend' basis. Initially, Grameen Danone agreed to pay an annual dividend of one percent to shareholders, however, in December 2009, the board of Grameen Danone agreed to waive any monetary return.[1] Grameen Danone Foods Grameen Danone social business enterprise nutrients Bangladesh shareholders [1] [1] [ ]  History[edit] History [edit] [ edit edit ] During his visit to Paris, France, in 2005, Muhammad Yunus, the founder of Grameen Bank was invited by Franck Riboud, the chief executive officer of Groupe Danone (known as Dannon in the US).  On 12 October 2005, they met in La Fontaine Gaillon, a Parisian restaurant.  There Yunus proposed to form a joint venture between Grameen and Danone with the objective of supplying nutritious food to poor children of Bangladesh.  As proposed by Muhammad Yunus, Franck Riboud agreed to participate in the project to be styled a social business.[2] Accordingly, the Grameen Group and Groupe Danone entered into an agreement to form a company called Grameen Danone Foods – a social business in Bangladesh.[3] The objective was to bring daily healthy nutrition to low income nutritionally deprived populations in Bangladesh and alleviate poverty through the implementation of a community based business model, where no profit will be appropriated by the investing partners.[4] Muhammad Yunus Grameen Bank Groupe Danone Grameen Danone social business [2] [2] [ ] social business [3] [3] [ ] [4] [4] [ ] The launch of Grameen Danone received considerable attention and was attended by celebrities including French soccer player Zinedine Zidane of France.[5] Zinedine Zidane [5] [5] [ ] Grameen Danone was led by Corinne Bazina from 2010 to 2014, Eric Ipavec from 2014 to 2016, Valérie Mazon from 2017 to 2018, and Dipesh Nag since 2020. Products and price[edit] Products and price [edit] [ edit edit ] Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. produces a yoghurt called Shokti Doi containing protein, vitamins, iron, calcium, zinc and other micronutrients aimed to fill nutritional deficits of children in Bangladesh.  'Shokti Doi' (which means 'strength yoghurt') is primarily intended for children. In 2017, a 50g cup sold for 10 Taka and 80g cup for 40 taka. Shokti Doi protein vitamins calcium zinc micronutrients Objective[edit] Objective [edit] [ edit edit ] Grameen Danone Foods aims to reduce poverty by creating business and employment opportunities for local people since raw materials including milk needed for production, will be sourced locally.  The companies that make up Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. have agreed not to take out any of the profits out of the company.  Instead they will invest these for creation of new opportunities for the welfare and development of people.  Hence it is called 'social business enterprise'.[4] [4] [4] [ ] Production capacity[edit] Production capacity [edit] [ edit edit ] Grameen Danone has planned to set up and launch as many as 50 production plants during the ten years between 2006 and 2016.[6] The first factory has been built in Bogra district which is about 230 kilometres (140 mi) north of Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh.  The first factory is a small one built upon an area of 7,000 sq ft (650 m2).[7] Its daily production capacity was 3,000 kilograms (6,600 lb) of yogurt when launched in 2006. In 2008, the production capacity has been planned to be enhanced to 10,000 kilograms (22,000 lb) and beyond.  Several hundred livestock-farming and distribution jobs would be created in the local community as a result of establishment of the first factory.[4] As of 2011, the company had not opened another factory.[8] [6] [6] [ ] Bogra Dhaka 2 [7] [7] [ ] [4] [4] [ ] [8] [8] [ ] Challenges[edit] Challenges [edit] [ edit edit ] Grameen Danone maintains strict quality control for Shokti Doi. The cold chain is maintained all the way from production to the end consumers. But maintaining cold chain is very expensive in Bangladesh as the traffic gridlock is a common scenario. Costly transportation is eating up a big portion of the return, thus could not reach its break-even till date. cold chain References[edit] References [edit] [ edit edit ] .mw-parser-output .navbox-list-with-group{text-align:left;border-left-width:2px;border-left-style:solid}.mw-parser-output tr+tr>.navbox-abovebelow,.mw-parser-output tr+tr>.navbox-group,.mw-parser-output tr+tr>.navbox-image,.mw-parser-output tr+tr>.navbox-list{border-top:2px solid #fdfdfd}.mw-parser-output .navbox-title{background-color:#ccf}.mw-parser-output .navbox-abovebelow,.mw-parser-output .navbox-group,.mw-parser-output .navbox-subgroup .navbox-title{background-color:#ddf}.mw-parser-output .navbox-subgroup .navbox-group,.mw-parser-output .navbox-subgroup .navbox-abovebelow{background-color:#e6e6ff}.mw-parser-output .navbox-even{background-color:#f7f7f7}.mw-parser-output .navbox-odd{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .navbox .hlist td     ".mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-left:10px solid #36c;background-color:#fbfbfb;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+link+.ambox{margin-top:-1px}html body.mediawiki .mw-parser-output .ambox.mbox-small-left{margin:4px 1em 4px 0;overflow:hidden;width:238px;border-collapse:collapse;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em}.mw-parser-output .ambox-speedy{border-left:10px solid #b32424;background-color:#fee7e6}.mw-parser-output .ambox-delete{border-left:10px solid #b32424}.mw-parser-output .ambox-content{border-left:10px solid #f28500}.mw-parser-output .ambox-style{border-left:10px solid #fc3}.mw-parser-output .ambox-move{border-left:10px solid #9932cc}.mw-parser-output .ambox-protection{border-left:10px solid #a2a9b1}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-text{border:none;padding:0.25em 0.5em;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image{border:none;padding:2px 0 2px 0.5em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-imageright{border:none;padding:2px 0.5em 2px 0;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-empty-cell{border:none;padding:0;width:1px}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image-div{width:52px}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .ambox{margin:0 10%}}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .ambox{display:none!important}}This article needs additional citations for verification. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR  (February 2008) (Learn how and when to remove this message) Grameen Danone Foods, popularly known as Grameen Danone, is a social business enterprise, launched in 2006, which has been designed to provide children with many of the key nutrients that are typically missing from their diet in rural Bangladesh.  It is run on 'No loss, No dividend' basis. Initially, Grameen Danone agreed to pay an annual dividend of one percent to shareholders, however, in December 2009, the board of Grameen Danone agreed to waive any monetary return.[1]   History[edit] During his visit to Paris, France, in 2005, Muhammad Yunus, the founder of Grameen Bank was invited by Franck Riboud, the chief executive officer of Groupe Danone (known as Dannon in the US).  On 12 October 2005, they met in La Fontaine Gaillon, a Parisian restaurant.  There Yunus proposed to form a joint venture between Grameen and Danone with the objective of supplying nutritious food to poor children of Bangladesh.  As proposed by Muhammad Yunus, Franck Riboud agreed to participate in the project to be styled a social business.[2] Accordingly, the Grameen Group and Groupe Danone entered into an agreement to form a company called Grameen Danone Foods – a social business in Bangladesh.[3] The objective was to bring daily healthy nutrition to low income nutritionally deprived populations in Bangladesh and alleviate poverty through the implementation of a community based business model, where no profit will be appropriated by the investing partners.[4] The launch of Grameen Danone received considerable attention and was attended by celebrities including French soccer player Zinedine Zidane of France.[5] Grameen Danone was led by Corinne Bazina from 2010 to 2014, Eric Ipavec from 2014 to 2016, Valérie Mazon from 2017 to 2018, and Dipesh Nag since 2020.  Products and price[edit] Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. produces a yoghurt called Shokti Doi containing protein, vitamins, iron, calcium, zinc and other micronutrients aimed to fill nutritional deficits of children in Bangladesh.  'Shokti Doi' (which means 'strength yoghurt') is primarily intended for children. In 2017, a 50g cup sold for 10 Taka and 80g cup for 40 taka.  Objective[edit] Grameen Danone Foods aims to reduce poverty by creating business and employment opportunities for local people since raw materials including milk needed for production, will be sourced locally.  The companies that make up Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. have agreed not to take out any of the profits out of the company.  Instead they will invest these for creation of new opportunities for the welfare and development of people.  Hence it is called 'social business enterprise'.[4]  Production capacity[edit] Grameen Danone has planned to set up and launch as many as 50 production plants during the ten years between 2006 and 2016.[6] The first factory has been built in Bogra district which is about 230 kilometres (140 mi) north of Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh.  The first factory is a small one built upon an area of 7,000 sq ft (650 m2).[7] Its daily production capacity was 3,000 kilograms (6,600 lb) of yogurt when launched in 2006. In 2008, the production capacity has been planned to be enhanced to 10,000 kilograms (22,000 lb) and beyond.  Several hundred livestock-farming and distribution jobs would be created in the local community as a result of establishment of the first factory.[4] As of 2011, the company had not opened another factory.[8]  Challenges[edit] Grameen Danone maintains strict quality control for Shokti Doi. The cold chain is maintained all the way from production to the end consumers. But maintaining cold chain is very expensive in Bangladesh as the traffic gridlock is a common scenario. Costly transportation is eating up a big portion of the return, thus could not reach its break-even till date. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR  (February 2008) (Learn how and when to remove this message) Grameen Danone Foods, popularly known as Grameen Danone, is a social business enterprise, launched in 2006, which has been designed to provide children with many of the key nutrients that are typically missing from their diet in rural Bangladesh.  It is run on 'No loss, No dividend' basis. Initially, Grameen Danone agreed to pay an annual dividend of one percent to shareholders, however, in December 2009, the board of Grameen Danone agreed to waive any monetary return.[1]   History[edit] During his visit to Paris, France, in 2005, Muhammad Yunus, the founder of Grameen Bank was invited by Franck Riboud, the chief executive officer of Groupe Danone (known as Dannon in the US).  On 12 October 2005, they met in La Fontaine Gaillon, a Parisian restaurant.  There Yunus proposed to form a joint venture between Grameen and Danone with the objective of supplying nutritious food to poor children of Bangladesh.  As proposed by Muhammad Yunus, Franck Riboud agreed to participate in the project to be styled a social business.[2] Accordingly, the Grameen Group and Groupe Danone entered into an agreement to form a company called Grameen Danone Foods – a social business in Bangladesh.[3] The objective was to bring daily healthy nutrition to low income nutritionally deprived populations in Bangladesh and alleviate poverty through the implementation of a community based business model, where no profit will be appropriated by the investing partners.[4] The launch of Grameen Danone received considerable attention and was attended by celebrities including French soccer player Zinedine Zidane of France.[5] Grameen Danone was led by Corinne Bazina from 2010 to 2014, Eric Ipavec from 2014 to 2016, Valérie Mazon from 2017 to 2018, and Dipesh Nag since 2020.  Products and price[edit] Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. produces a yoghurt called Shokti Doi containing protein, vitamins, iron, calcium, zinc and other micronutrients aimed to fill nutritional deficits of children in Bangladesh.  'Shokti Doi' (which means 'strength yoghurt') is primarily intended for children. In 2017, a 50g cup sold for 10 Taka and 80g cup for 40 taka.  Objective[edit] Grameen Danone Foods aims to reduce poverty by creating business and employment opportunities for local people since raw materials including milk needed for production, will be sourced locally.  The companies that make up Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. have agreed not to take out any of the profits out of the company.  Instead they will invest these for creation of new opportunities for the welfare and development of people.  Hence it is called 'social business enterprise'.[4]  Production capacity[edit] Grameen Danone has planned to set up and launch as many as 50 production plants during the ten years between 2006 and 2016.[6] The first factory has been built in Bogra district which is about 230 kilometres (140 mi) north of Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh.  The first factory is a small one built upon an area of 7,000 sq ft (650 m2).[7] Its daily production capacity was 3,000 kilograms (6,600 lb) of yogurt when launched in 2006. In 2008, the production capacity has been planned to be enhanced to 10,000 kilograms (22,000 lb) and beyond.  Several hundred livestock-farming and distribution jobs would be created in the local community as a result of establishment of the first factory.[4] As of 2011, the company had not opened another factory.[8]  Challenges[edit] Grameen Danone maintains strict quality control for Shokti Doi. The cold chain is maintained all the way from production to the end consumers. But maintaining cold chain is very expensive in Bangladesh as the traffic gridlock is a common scenario. Costly transportation is eating up a big portion of the return, thus could not reach its break-even till date. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR  (February 2008) (Learn how and when to remove this message) needs additional citations for verification verification Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR improve this article adding citations to reliable sources  Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR (February 2008) (February 2008) February 2008 (Learn how and when to remove this message) (Learn how and when to remove this message) Learn how and when to remove this message Learn how and when to remove this message Grameen Danone Foods, popularly known as Grameen Danone, is a social business enterprise, launched in 2006, which has been designed to provide children with many of the key nutrients that are typically missing from their diet in rural Bangladesh.  It is run on 'No loss, No dividend' basis. Initially, Grameen Danone agreed to pay an annual dividend of one percent to shareholders, however, in December 2009, the board of Grameen Danone agreed to waive any monetary return.[1] Grameen Danone Foods Grameen Danone social business enterprise nutrients Bangladesh shareholders [1] [1] [ ]  History[edit] History [edit] [ edit edit ] During his visit to Paris, France, in 2005, Muhammad Yunus, the founder of Grameen Bank was invited by Franck Riboud, the chief executive officer of Groupe Danone (known as Dannon in the US).  On 12 October 2005, they met in La Fontaine Gaillon, a Parisian restaurant.  There Yunus proposed to form a joint venture between Grameen and Danone with the objective of supplying nutritious food to poor children of Bangladesh.  As proposed by Muhammad Yunus, Franck Riboud agreed to participate in the project to be styled a social business.[2] Accordingly, the Grameen Group and Groupe Danone entered into an agreement to form a company called Grameen Danone Foods – a social business in Bangladesh.[3] The objective was to bring daily healthy nutrition to low income nutritionally deprived populations in Bangladesh and alleviate poverty through the implementation of a community based business model, where no profit will be appropriated by the investing partners.[4] Muhammad Yunus Grameen Bank Groupe Danone Grameen Danone social business [2] [2] [ ] social business [3] [3] [ ] [4] [4] [ ] The launch of Grameen Danone received considerable attention and was attended by celebrities including French soccer player Zinedine Zidane of France.[5] Zinedine Zidane [5] [5] [ ] Grameen Danone was led by Corinne Bazina from 2010 to 2014, Eric Ipavec from 2014 to 2016, Valérie Mazon from 2017 to 2018, and Dipesh Nag since 2020. Products and price[edit] Products and price [edit] [ edit edit ] Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. produces a yoghurt called Shokti Doi containing protein, vitamins, iron, calcium, zinc and other micronutrients aimed to fill nutritional deficits of children in Bangladesh.  'Shokti Doi' (which means 'strength yoghurt') is primarily intended for children. In 2017, a 50g cup sold for 10 Taka and 80g cup for 40 taka. Shokti Doi protein vitamins calcium zinc micronutrients Objective[edit] Objective [edit] [ edit edit ] Grameen Danone Foods aims to reduce poverty by creating business and employment opportunities for local people since raw materials including milk needed for production, will be sourced locally.  The companies that make up Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. have agreed not to take out any of the profits out of the company.  Instead they will invest these for creation of new opportunities for the welfare and development of people.  Hence it is called 'social business enterprise'.[4] [4] [4] [ ] Production capacity[edit] Production capacity [edit] [ edit edit ] Grameen Danone has planned to set up and launch as many as 50 production plants during the ten years between 2006 and 2016.[6] The first factory has been built in Bogra district which is about 230 kilometres (140 mi) north of Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh.  The first factory is a small one built upon an area of 7,000 sq ft (650 m2).[7] Its daily production capacity was 3,000 kilograms (6,600 lb) of yogurt when launched in 2006. In 2008, the production capacity has been planned to be enhanced to 10,000 kilograms (22,000 lb) and beyond.  Several hundred livestock-farming and distribution jobs would be created in the local community as a result of establishment of the first factory.[4] As of 2011, the company had not opened another factory.[8] [6] [6] [ ] Bogra Dhaka 2 [7] [7] [ ] [4] [4] [ ] [8] [8] [ ] Challenges[edit] Challenges [edit] [ edit edit ] Grameen Danone maintains strict quality control for Shokti Doi. The cold chain is maintained all the way from production to the end consumers. But maintaining cold chain is very expensive in Bangladesh as the traffic gridlock is a common scenario. Costly transportation is eating up a big portion of the return, thus could not reach its break-even till date. cold chain References[edit] References [edit] [ edit edit ] .mw-parser-output     ".mw-parser-output .ambox{border:1px solid #a2a9b1;border-left:10px solid #36c;background-color:#fbfbfb;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+link+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+style+.ambox,.mw-parser-output .ambox+.mw-empty-elt+link+link+.ambox{margin-top:-1px}html body.mediawiki .mw-parser-output .ambox.mbox-small-left{margin:4px 1em 4px 0;overflow:hidden;width:238px;border-collapse:collapse;font-size:88%;line-height:1.25em}.mw-parser-output .ambox-speedy{border-left:10px solid #b32424;background-color:#fee7e6}.mw-parser-output .ambox-delete{border-left:10px solid #b32424}.mw-parser-output .ambox-content{border-left:10px solid #f28500}.mw-parser-output .ambox-style{border-left:10px solid #fc3}.mw-parser-output .ambox-move{border-left:10px solid #9932cc}.mw-parser-output .ambox-protection{border-left:10px solid #a2a9b1}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-text{border:none;padding:0.25em 0.5em;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image{border:none;padding:2px 0 2px 0.5em;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-imageright{border:none;padding:2px 0.5em 2px 0;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-empty-cell{border:none;padding:0;width:1px}.mw-parser-output .ambox .mbox-image-div{width:52px}@media(min-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .ambox{margin:0 10%}}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .ambox{display:none!important}}This article needs additional citations for verification. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR  (February 2008) (Learn how and when to remove this message) Grameen Danone Foods, popularly known as Grameen Danone, is a social business enterprise, launched in 2006, which has been designed to provide children with many of the key nutrients that are typically missing from their diet in rural Bangladesh.  It is run on 'No loss, No dividend' basis. Initially, Grameen Danone agreed to pay an annual dividend of one percent to shareholders, however, in December 2009, the board of Grameen Danone agreed to waive any monetary return.[1]   History[edit] During his visit to Paris, France, in 2005, Muhammad Yunus, the founder of Grameen Bank was invited by Franck Riboud, the chief executive officer of Groupe Danone (known as Dannon in the US).  On 12 October 2005, they met in La Fontaine Gaillon, a Parisian restaurant.  There Yunus proposed to form a joint venture between Grameen and Danone with the objective of supplying nutritious food to poor children of Bangladesh.  As proposed by Muhammad Yunus, Franck Riboud agreed to participate in the project to be styled a social business.[2] Accordingly, the Grameen Group and Groupe Danone entered into an agreement to form a company called Grameen Danone Foods – a social business in Bangladesh.[3] The objective was to bring daily healthy nutrition to low income nutritionally deprived populations in Bangladesh and alleviate poverty through the implementation of a community based business model, where no profit will be appropriated by the investing partners.[4] The launch of Grameen Danone received considerable attention and was attended by celebrities including French soccer player Zinedine Zidane of France.[5] Grameen Danone was led by Corinne Bazina from 2010 to 2014, Eric Ipavec from 2014 to 2016, Valérie Mazon from 2017 to 2018, and Dipesh Nag since 2020.  Products and price[edit] Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. produces a yoghurt called Shokti Doi containing protein, vitamins, iron, calcium, zinc and other micronutrients aimed to fill nutritional deficits of children in Bangladesh.  'Shokti Doi' (which means 'strength yoghurt') is primarily intended for children. In 2017, a 50g cup sold for 10 Taka and 80g cup for 40 taka.  Objective[edit] Grameen Danone Foods aims to reduce poverty by creating business and employment opportunities for local people since raw materials including milk needed for production, will be sourced locally.  The companies that make up Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. have agreed not to take out any of the profits out of the company.  Instead they will invest these for creation of new opportunities for the welfare and development of people.  Hence it is called 'social business enterprise'.[4]  Production capacity[edit] Grameen Danone has planned to set up and launch as many as 50 production plants during the ten years between 2006 and 2016.[6] The first factory has been built in Bogra district which is about 230 kilometres (140 mi) north of Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh.  The first factory is a small one built upon an area of 7,000 sq ft (650 m2).[7] Its daily production capacity was 3,000 kilograms (6,600 lb) of yogurt when launched in 2006. In 2008, the production capacity has been planned to be enhanced to 10,000 kilograms (22,000 lb) and beyond.  Several hundred livestock-farming and distribution jobs would be created in the local community as a result of establishment of the first factory.[4] As of 2011, the company had not opened another factory.[8]  Challenges[edit] Grameen Danone maintains strict quality control for Shokti Doi. The cold chain is maintained all the way from production to the end consumers. But maintaining cold chain is very expensive in Bangladesh as the traffic gridlock is a common scenario. Costly transportation is eating up a big portion of the return, thus could not reach its break-even till date. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR  (February 2008) (Learn how and when to remove this message) needs additional citations for verification verification Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed.Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR improve this article adding citations to reliable sources  Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" – news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR Find sources: \"Grameen Danone\" news · newspapers · books · scholar · JSTOR (February 2008) (February 2008) February 2008 (Learn how and when to remove this message) (Learn how and when to remove this message) Learn how and when to remove this message Learn how and when to remove this message Grameen Danone Foods, popularly known as Grameen Danone, is a social business enterprise, launched in 2006, which has been designed to provide children with many of the key nutrients that are typically missing from their diet in rural Bangladesh.  It is run on 'No loss, No dividend' basis. Initially, Grameen Danone agreed to pay an annual dividend of one percent to shareholders, however, in December 2009, the board of Grameen Danone agreed to waive any monetary return.[1] Grameen Danone Foods Grameen Danone social business enterprise nutrients Bangladesh shareholders [1] [1] [ ]  History[edit] History [edit] [ edit edit ] During his visit to Paris, France, in 2005, Muhammad Yunus, the founder of Grameen Bank was invited by Franck Riboud, the chief executive officer of Groupe Danone (known as Dannon in the US).  On 12 October 2005, they met in La Fontaine Gaillon, a Parisian restaurant.  There Yunus proposed to form a joint venture between Grameen and Danone with the objective of supplying nutritious food to poor children of Bangladesh.  As proposed by Muhammad Yunus, Franck Riboud agreed to participate in the project to be styled a social business.[2] Accordingly, the Grameen Group and Groupe Danone entered into an agreement to form a company called Grameen Danone Foods – a social business in Bangladesh.[3] The objective was to bring daily healthy nutrition to low income nutritionally deprived populations in Bangladesh and alleviate poverty through the implementation of a community based business model, where no profit will be appropriated by the investing partners.[4] Muhammad Yunus Grameen Bank Groupe Danone Grameen Danone social business [2] [2] [ ] social business [3] [3] [ ] [4] [4] [ ] The launch of Grameen Danone received considerable attention and was attended by celebrities including French soccer player Zinedine Zidane of France.[5] Zinedine Zidane [5] [5] [ ] Grameen Danone was led by Corinne Bazina from 2010 to 2014, Eric Ipavec from 2014 to 2016, Valérie Mazon from 2017 to 2018, and Dipesh Nag since 2020. Products and price[edit] Products and price [edit] [ edit edit ] Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. produces a yoghurt called Shokti Doi containing protein, vitamins, iron, calcium, zinc and other micronutrients aimed to fill nutritional deficits of children in Bangladesh.  'Shokti Doi' (which means 'strength yoghurt') is primarily intended for children. In 2017, a 50g cup sold for 10 Taka and 80g cup for 40 taka. Shokti Doi protein vitamins calcium zinc micronutrients Objective[edit] Objective [edit] [ edit edit ] Grameen Danone Foods aims to reduce poverty by creating business and employment opportunities for local people since raw materials including milk needed for production, will be sourced locally.  The companies that make up Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. have agreed not to take out any of the profits out of the company.  Instead they will invest these for creation of new opportunities for the welfare and development of people.  Hence it is called 'social business enterprise'.[4] [4] [4] [ ] Production capacity[edit] Production capacity [edit] [ edit edit ] Grameen Danone has planned to set up and launch as many as 50 production plants during the ten years between 2006 and 2016.[6] The first factory has been built in Bogra district which is about 230 kilometres (140 mi) north of Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh.  The first factory is a small one built upon an area of 7,000 sq ft (650 m2).[7] Its daily production capacity was 3,000 kilograms (6,600 lb) of yogurt when launched in 2006. In 2008, the production capacity has been planned to be enhanced to 10,000 kilograms (22,000 lb) and beyond.  Several hundred livestock-farming and distribution jobs would be created in the local community as a result of establishment of the first factory.[4] As of 2011, the company had not opened another factory.[8] [6] [6] [ ] Bogra Dhaka 2 [7] [7] [ ] [4] [4] [ ] [8] [8] [ ] Challenges[edit] Challenges [edit] [ edit edit ] Grameen Danone maintains strict quality control for Shokti Doi. The cold chain is maintained all the way from production to the end consumers. But maintaining cold chain is very expensive in Bangladesh as the traffic gridlock is a common scenario. Costly transportation is eating up a big portion of the return, thus could not reach its break-even till date. cold chain References[edit] References [edit] [ edit edit ] .mw-parser-output   "pData": [
    "Grameen Danone Foods, popularly known as Grameen Danone, is a social business enterprise, launched in 2006, which has been designed to provide children with many of the key nutrients that are typically missing from their diet in rural Bangladesh.  It is run on 'No loss, No dividend' basis. Initially, Grameen Danone agreed to pay an annual dividend of one percent to shareholders, however, in December 2009, the board of Grameen Danone agreed to waive any monetary return.[1] Grameen Danone Foods Grameen Danone social business enterprise nutrients Bangladesh shareholders [1] [1] [ ]",
    "During his visit to Paris, France, in 2005, Muhammad Yunus, the founder of Grameen Bank was invited by Franck Riboud, the chief executive officer of Groupe Danone (known as Dannon in the US).  On 12 October 2005, they met in La Fontaine Gaillon, a Parisian restaurant.  There Yunus proposed to form a joint venture between Grameen and Danone with the objective of supplying nutritious food to poor children of Bangladesh.  As proposed by Muhammad Yunus, Franck Riboud agreed to participate in the project to be styled a social business.[2] Accordingly, the Grameen Group and Groupe Danone entered into an agreement to form a company called Grameen Danone Foods – a social business in Bangladesh.[3] The objective was to bring daily healthy nutrition to low income nutritionally deprived populations in Bangladesh and alleviate poverty through the implementation of a community based business model, where no profit will be appropriated by the investing partners.[4] Muhammad Yunus Grameen Bank Groupe Danone Grameen Danone social business [2] [2] [ ] social business [3] [3] [ ] [4] [4] [ ]",
    "The launch of Grameen Danone received considerable attention and was attended by celebrities including French soccer player Zinedine Zidane of France.[5] Zinedine Zidane [5] [5] [ ]",
    "Grameen Danone was led by Corinne Bazina from 2010 to 2014, Eric Ipavec from 2014 to 2016, Valérie Mazon from 2017 to 2018, and Dipesh Nag since 2020.",
    "Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. produces a yoghurt called Shokti Doi containing protein, vitamins, iron, calcium, zinc and other micronutrients aimed to fill nutritional deficits of children in Bangladesh.  'Shokti Doi' (which means 'strength yoghurt') is primarily intended for children. In 2017, a 50g cup sold for 10 Taka and 80g cup for 40 taka. Shokti Doi protein vitamins calcium zinc micronutrients",
    "Grameen Danone Foods aims to reduce poverty by creating business and employment opportunities for local people since raw materials including milk needed for production, will be sourced locally.  The companies that make up Grameen Danone Foods Ltd. have agreed not to take out any of the profits out of the company.  Instead they will invest these for creation of new opportunities for the welfare and development of people.  Hence it is called 'social business enterprise'.[4] [4] [4] [ ]",
    "Grameen Danone has planned to set up and launch as many as 50 production plants during the ten years between 2006 and 2016.[6] The first factory has been built in Bogra district which is about 230 kilometres (140 mi) north of Dhaka, the capital city of Bangladesh.  The first factory is a small one built upon an area of 7,000 sq ft (650 m2).[7] Its daily production capacity was 3,000 kilograms (6,600 lb) of yogurt when launched in 2006. In 2008, the production capacity has been planned to be enhanced to 10,000 kilograms (22,000 lb) and beyond.  Several hundred livestock-farming and distribution jobs would be created in the local community as a result of establishment of the first factory.[4] As of 2011, the company had not opened another factory.[8] [6] [6] [ ] Bogra Dhaka 2 [7] [7] [ ] [4] [4] [ ] [8] [8] [ ]",
    "Grameen Danone maintains strict quality control for Shokti Doi. The cold chain is maintained all the way from production to the end consumers. But maintaining cold chain is very expensive in Bangladesh as the traffic gridlock is a common scenario. Costly transportation is eating up a big portion of the return, thus could not reach its break-even till date. cold chain"
  ],

    "SUSTAINABILITY IMPACT         Social & Environmental Responsibility SUSTAINABILITY IMPACT Social & Environmental Responsibility Social & Environmental Responsibility",
    "Social & Environmental Responsibility Social & Environmental Responsibility",
    "#shopify-section-template--23802925154649__text_section_PkqTrc{    padding-top:30px;    padding-bottom:0px;   }    @media screen and (min-width: 768px) {    #shopify-section-template--23802925154649__text_section_PkqTrc{     padding-top:50px;     padding-bottom:0px;    }   }   The development of an affordable, eco-friendly water filter with health assurances has made significant strides in social and environmental protection. This endeavor aligns closely with the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals established by the United Nations.Through its social program, which focuses on delivering water filters to rural schools in Guatemala, Ecofiltro has positively impacted the lives of approximately 1 million families in these regions. By providing access to safe drinking water, Ecofiltro has markedly enhanced their quality of life.Operating on a \"social business\" model, a portion of the filter sales in urban areas finances the distribution of filters in rural regions. Between 2014 and 2022, this approach facilitated the distribution of 33,751 Ecofiltros to 6,210 schools.Furthermore, Ecofiltro has made significant environmental contributions by substantially reducing carbon emissions. By eliminating the need to boil water for purification, Ecofiltro has led to a reduction of approximately 459,097 tons in firewood usage, equivalent to saving 500,000 trees in the country and mitigating the risk of deforestation.On a global scale, Ecofiltro plays a vital role in combating plastic pollution, particularly in oceans and seas. This technology reduces reliance on non-biodegradable packaging, thereby addressing one of the most pressing environmental crises of our time. With its presence in Europe, Ecofiltro contributes to saving approximately 6.5 million plastic bottles annually.In recognition of Ecofiltro's commitment to social and environmental responsibility, we proudly achieved B Corp certification in February 2020. This milestone further underscores our dedication to promoting sustainable practices and enhancing public health.Join us in our mission to create positive social and environmental change. Together, we can make a meaningful difference in the lives of communities worldwide and safeguard our planet for future generations, all through the use of Ecofiltro.  #shopify-section-template--23802925154649__text_section_PkqTrc{    padding-top:30px;    padding-bottom:0px;   }    @media screen and (min-width: 768px) {    #shopify-section-template--23802925154649__text_section_PkqTrc{     padding-top:50px;     padding-bottom:0px;    }   } The development of an affordable, eco-friendly water filter with health assurances has made significant strides in social and environmental protection. This endeavor aligns closely with the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals established by the United Nations.Through its social program, which focuses on delivering water filters to rural schools in Guatemala, Ecofiltro has positively impacted the lives of approximately 1 million families in these regions. By providing access to safe drinking water, Ecofiltro has markedly enhanced their quality of life.Operating on a \"social business\" model, a portion of the filter sales in urban areas finances the distribution of filters in rural regions. Between 2014 and 2022, this approach facilitated the distribution of 33,751 Ecofiltros to 6,210 schools.Furthermore, Ecofiltro has made significant environmental contributions by substantially reducing carbon emissions. By eliminating the need to boil water for purification, Ecofiltro has led to a reduction of approximately 459,097 tons in firewood usage, equivalent to saving 500,000 trees in the country and mitigating the risk of deforestation.On a global scale, Ecofiltro plays a vital role in combating plastic pollution, particularly in oceans and seas. This technology reduces reliance on non-biodegradable packaging, thereby addressing one of the most pressing environmental crises of our time. With its presence in Europe, Ecofiltro contributes to saving approximately 6.5 million plastic bottles annually.In recognition of Ecofiltro's commitment to social and environmental responsibility, we proudly achieved B Corp certification in February 2020. This milestone further underscores our dedication to promoting sustainable practices and enhancing public health.Join us in our mission to create positive social and environmental change. Together, we can make a meaningful difference in the lives of communities worldwide and safeguard our planet for future generations, all through the use of Ecofiltro.
